title: Finger Ring with Intaglio Depicting Eros

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of gold and banded stone or glass.

description:
For both men and women in the Roman world, jewelry functioned as a visible sign of wealth, social standing,
and gender. Artists of the time created some works in accord with earlier Hellenistic and Etruscan preferences
for the extravagant and conspicuous use of gold. Over time, imperial expansion increased Romans’ access to a variety of valuable materials, leading to a distinctly Roman taste for jewelry incorporating color—typically in the form of gemstones or glass, as seen in this ring.
medium_display: Gold and banded stone or glass
credit_line: Gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection
publication_history:
The Ralph Harari Collection of Finger Rings, John Boardman and Diana Scarisbrick, Thames and Hudson, London, 1977, no 37, pp 28-29 (ill.)

Sotheby & Co., London, Catalogue of the Superb Collection of Rings, Nov. 10, 1937, no. 317, p. 67, plate X1. 

Catalogue of a Collection of Ancient Rings Formed by the Late E. Guilhou, Seymour de Ricci, Paris, 1912, no. 222 (ill.).
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Of Gods and Glamour: The Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine Art, Gallery 151, April 18, 2014 - present.
provenance_text: Édouard Guilhou, Paris; the estate of Édouard Guilhou, Paris, by 1912; sold, Sotheby’s London, November 10, 1937, lot 317, to Ralph Andrew Harari (died 1969), London and Cairo; by descent to the Harari family, London; sold, S.J. Philips Ltd., London, 1975. Dorothy Braude Edinburg; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.
department_title: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
category_titles: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium

input: Finger Ring with Intaglio Depicting Eros
